ygData.msgSnippet: Yes, the setup is like you described. I m using the standard arc writer and I checked the arc files to see the type. Besides application/xml content, the other

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Yes, the setup is like you described. I'm using the standard arc writer
and=
 I checked the arc files to see the type. Besides application/xml
content, =
the other ones are all text/html. Here are the settings for
parts where I d=
o have filters and such.

1) On the scope:  I put the huge regex on separat=
e lines for easier
read.
rejectByDefault
acceptIfSurtPrefixed
rejectIfTooMa=
nyHops
rejectIfPathological
rejectIfTooManyPathSegs
acceptIfPrerequisite

<=
newObject name=3D"Match"
class=3D"org.archive.crawler.deciderules.MatchesRe=
gExpDecideRule">
<string name=3D"decision">REJECT</string>
<string name=3D"=
regexp">
.*(?i)\.(a|ai|aif|aifc|aiff|asc|asp|avi|bat|bcpio|bin|bmp|bz2|c|cd=
f|cfm|\
cgi|cgm|
class|cpio|cpp|cpt|csh|css|cxx|dcr|dif|dir|djv|djvu|dll|dm=
g|dms|doc|dtd|\
dv|dvi|
dxr|eps|etx|exe|ez|gram|grxml|gtar|gz|gif|h|html|ht=
m|hdf|hqx|ice|ico|ics\
|ief|ifb|
iges|igs|iso|jnlp|jp2|jpe|jpeg|jpg|js|jsp|=
kar|latex|lha|lzh|m3u|mac|man|\
mathml|me|
mm|mesh|mid|midi|mif|mov|movie|m=
p2|mp3|mp4|mpe|mpeg|mpg|mpga|ms|msh|mxu|
nc|o|oda|odt|old|ogg|pbm|pct|pdb|p=
df|pgm|pgn|php|pic|pict|pl|png|pjpeg|p\
nm|pnt|pntg|
ppm|ppt|ps|py|qt|qti|q=
tif|ra|ram|ras|rdf|rgb|rm|roff|rpm|rtf|rtx|s|sgm|s\
gml|sh|shar|shtml|
silo=
|sit|skd|skm|skp|skt|smi|smil|snd|so|spl|sql|src|srpm|sv4cpio|sv4crc\
|svg|=
swf|sxd|sxw|t|
tar|tcl|tex|texi|tpl|texinfo|tgz|tif|tiff|tr|tsv|ustar|vcd|v=
rml|vxml|wav\
|wbmp|wbxml|wml|wmv
|wmlc|wmls|wmlsc|wrl|xbm|xht|xhtml|xls|xp=
m|xslt|xwd|xyz|z|zip)$

2) On the midfetch-decide-rulesand Archiver#decide-=
rules I have the same
thing.
<newObject name=3D"Archiver#decide-rules"
clas=
s=3D"org.archive.crawler.deciderules.DecideRuleSequence">
<map name=3D"rule=
s">
<newObject name=3D"rejectdefault"
class=3D"org.archive.crawler.decideru=
les.RejectDecideRule">
             </newObject>
<newObject name=3D"fetch"
=
class=3D"org.archive.crawler.deciderules.FetchStatusDecideRule">
<string na=
me=3D"decision">ACCEPT</string>
<integer name=3D"target-status">200</intege=
r>
</newObject>
<newObject name=3D"content"
class=3D"org.archive.crawler.de=
ciderules.ContentTypeMatchesRegExpDecideRul\
e">
<string name=3D"decision">=
ACCEPT</string>
<string name=3D"regexp">(?i)application/xml.*</string>
</ne=
wObject>
</map>
</newObject>

Thanks!
-Shawn
--- In archive-crawler@yahoogr=
oups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
>
> So if I may summarize:
>
> - =
You have a set of decide rules set up on the writer processor
> - these rul=
es begin with a REJECT-all rule, then have a
> ContentTypeMatchesRegexpDeci=
deRule set to only ACCEPT XML content
> - you still see HTML being written =
by that writer processor
>
> Is that correct?
>
> Some ideas:
> - are you u=
sing a non-standard writer that isn't consulting
> shouldProcess correctly?=

> - do you have multiple writer processors active, and another processor
>=
 is writing?
> - the content is actually coming back as XHTML, and has 'xml=
' in its
> content-type?
> - the writer-processor's decide-rules are someho=
w not-enabled?
> - an error in the regex is accepting everything?
>
> If it=
's none of these, feel free to send an excerpt of your
> configuration for =
the writer processor (from your heritrix1 order.xml
or
> heritrix2.0 global=
.sheet) for analysis.
>
> - Gordon @ IA
>
> lpeterus wrote:
> > I had a def=
ault REJECT in the scope to start with but not in the
> > mid-fetch or writ=
er processor phase. I also tried adding those in as
> > the first rule for =
them but with no success. The
> > ContentTypeMatchesRegexpDecideRule is con=
figured as accept with the
> > regex for xml content type. I got the idea f=
rom a previous post but
> > configured to just accept html content.
> > htt=
p://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/archive-crawler/message/2824
> >
> > -Shawn=

> >
> > --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr gojomo@ wrote:=

> >> Do you have a REJECT rule first that applies to everything, then
the
=
> >> ContentTypeMatchesRegExpDecideRule to ACCEPT the right kind of
content=
?
> >>
> >> Otherwise, the decision of the decide-rules will be ambiguous
(=
PASS),
> >> and in the case of Processor decide-rules, anything but a REJEC=
T
allows
> >> the Processor to run. (See Processor.process().)
> >>
> >> - =
Gordon @ IA
> >>
> >> lpeterus wrote:
> >>> Hi!
> >>>
> >>> Thanks for the =
reply. I did have a
ContentTypeMatchesRegExpDecideRule
> >>> under the writ=
er processor section with the following regex
> >>> (?i)application/xml.*
>=
 >>> But it still seems to be writing the text/html pages from dynamic
> >>=
> URLs. Did I use the wrong type of expression? Thanks.
> >>>
> >>> --- In =
archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "ermhes82" <ermhes@>
wrote:
> >>>> You can=
 prevent this if you include in decide-rules a
> >>>> ContentTypeMatchesReg=
ExpDecideRule o
> >>>> ContentTypeNotMatchesRegExpDecideRule.
> >>>>
> >>>>=
 Mario.
> >>>>
> >>>> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "lpeterus" <l=
peterus@>
wrote:
> >>>>> Hi all!
> >>>>>
> >>>>> I have a question about ho=
w to exclude dynamic URLs. I'm using
> > regular
> >>>>> expression rules b=
ased on suggestions from previous posting. I
would
> >>>>> like to filter o=
ut everything except for text/xml and
> > application/xml
> >>>>> files. Th=
e filters are applied on the scope, midfetch, and the
arc
> >>>>> writer pr=
ocessor.
> >>>>> So far everything works ok, except it still dowloads some
=
text/html
> >>>>> files even though html is part of the rejection regexp in=
 the
scope.
> >>>>> Turns out all of the text/html downloads are dynamic UR=
Ls like
> > this,
> >>>>> http://somewebpage/subdir/?C=3DD;O=3DA
> >>>>> My=
 question then is how do I prevent these text/html from being
> >>>>> writt=
en into the arc file. Thanks!
> >>>>>
> >>>>> Shawn
> >>>>>
> >>>
> >>>

> >>> Yahoo! Groups Links

>>
